In the matter of emergency response, the Emergency Contingency Plan (Orange Binder) should be referred to in the event of any emergency associated with the Los Angeles site. 

Any abnormal event which may threaten areas outside the plant perimeter, or which may require outside assistance to control shall be considered an emergency. Such events include but are not limited to: fires and explosions, uncontrollable spills and emissions, medical emergencies, workplace violence, and natural disasters. 
This site does not have a formal Emergency Response Team and therefore will evacuate employees in the event of a hazardous materials emergency. However, operations and maintenance employees are trained and knowledgeable of the hazards of the chemicals they work with daily, and therefore are expected to respond to incidental spills in the areas in which they work.

Since our last submittal, the site has implemented monthly safety meetings to discuss how to improve upon any environmental/safety incidents, including walkthroughs, inspections, and drills (specifically focusing on the regulated chemicals of Formaldehyde, EDA and Phenol).  We also plan on using the trends from our Accident Preventive Technique KPIs that are submitted by all employees each month to see where the site needs to improve and implement Corrective and Preventive actions. 

4. Five year accident history

Formaldehyde Release that resulted in an employee seeking medical attention for injuries sustained during event  November 1, 2020 Incident No. 19596. Employee was rinsing the reactor when fumes were inhaled, noticed a strong scent of formaldehyde and felt slight nausea with an acute irritation in their throat.

Immediate Actions Taken -Contacted supervision, went for fresh air, water and gatorade. Printed out SDS and went to clinic.

Corrective/Preventive Actions Taken - Updated procedure to follow formaldehyde neutralization steps with respirator any time there needs to be a line break especially for the first line break, even after it appears that all the formaldehyde has been neutralized.

There have been no accidents involving or accidental releases of either Ethylenediamene or Phenol (regulated under CalARP) that resulted in any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

Formaldehyde is used in the manufacture of epoxy curing agents. Formaldehyde is delivered via tank trucks and is stored in a double walled stainless steel underground storage tank. The formaldehyde is delivered to the reactors by a series of pumps and pipes. Once in the system, formaldehyde stays contained in the system. All the formaldehyde is consumed once it enters the reactors. The finished product does not contain any residual formaldehyde. The reaction is irreversible and exothermic. 

Phenol is used in the manufacture of epoxy curing agents. Phenol is delivered via tank trucks and is stored in a stainless steel above ground storage tank. The Phenol is delivered to the reactors by a series of pumps and pipes. Once in the system, phenol stays contained in the system. All the phenol is consumed once it enters the reactors. The finished product does not contain any residual phenol.

3. General accidental release prevention program and specific prevention steps

The facility developed a prevention program based on the elements of the Federal EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Program, the California Accidental Release Program and OSHA's Process Safety Management regulation.

The facility's PSM procedure will act as an overview of the various plant systems and procedures already in place to meet the guidelines set forth by OSHA Rule 1910.119 Process Safety Management. 

Chemical-specific release prevention steps:

-	Mechanical Integrity Program  ensuring proper preventative maintenance
-	Inspections & Audit Programs
-	SPCC Program
-	SWP Program
-	Wastewater Program  Redundant systems which test for pH prior to release
-	Incident Management Process
-	Drills  Performed annually with focus on regulated chemicals
-	PHAs

2. The facility and the regulated substances handled

The Los Angeles Plant operates four major reactors that manufacture mainly epoxy curing agents. Epoxy curing agents are used to manufacture paints, adhesives, composite materials and civil engineering floors. The plant's process uses various types of amines and modifies its properties using solvents, resins and other chemicals to make it easier to handle for consumers. Ethylenediamine (CAS# 107-15-3) and a 37% solution of formaldehyde (CAS # 50-0-0) in water are the two raw materials used on site that are on the Regulated substance list and have exceeded the threshold quantity for Federal EPA and CalARP requirements.  In addition, Phenol (CAS# 108-95-2) is also regulated under CalARP. 

Ethylenediamine is used in the manufacture of amine adducts. Ethylenediamine is received in 55 gallon drums. Ethylenediamine is transferred to the reactor and processed.
